years of LTS support so this is the idea that we're gonna take the patches that are released for updates for security
and maintenance and we're gonna make those available as backported patches to older versions of the LTS releases for
five years so in the past we would have released those updates and you kind of had a rolling release where you had to
upgrade everything else that might come along with a patch if you wanted to pull it in in this world you get that back
port that really lets you have a stable environment where your applications run against a very known set of libraries
and utilities and then you don't see those change underneath you as much which means that if you built for it you
expect performance to be a particular way you expect behavior to be a particular way it's gonna stay that way

think if you look at a lot of other distributions that are out there in the Linux space they've taken a mentality of having a very long term stable release
and then having something that's more cutting-edge and dynamic but they're full distributions one's kind of the
stable Enterprise version and one's kind of this dynamic changing you know maybe not so stable version and when we talked
to customers they said they were constantly having to pull stuff from that kind of more unstable version into
the older or more stable version and not necessarily feeling like it was supported and maybe there were package
dependency challenges and so we tried to look at this problem a different way and sort of say well maybe we can have that
more stable environment but we can have that environment of faster moving
packages available to run in that environment and so that's what the extras concept is we've got a core in
the LTS to release that's supported for five years and the list of that is all published on our website in terms of
what that repo contains it's most of the core runtime and executable components for Linux and then we have the extras

Linux community at the same time so Amazon workspaces are really simply desktops running inside of the AWS cloud
right so you're standing up either a Windows 7 or Windows 10 or now in this case a Linux desktop and then streaming
the video output from that so that is instead of having a video adapter connecting directly to a screen on a
laptop you've got an instance running an ec2 and you're streaming the video output down to a client running on
whatever device you want to connect from then we're capturing your keyboard and mouse movements and streaming them back
up into that environment and so you're interacting with the desktop it looks and feels just like your normal desktop
it's just actually running in the cloud you kind of can't tell the difference so the experience should be basically the
same but your desktop experience is not tied to your client device anymore so
you can connect from a Mac or you connect from Android device and still get to the apps you want in Windows or Linux which is pretty cool so at the
same time we really wanted to make it solve some of the challenges that people have had with virtual desktop
environments in the past VDI so it's a much simpler process you stand them up in ten or fifteen minutes we take care
of a huge amount of the administration and management so you don't have to become an expert and a lot of the VDI concepts to take advantage of this
globally for your whole company which is pretty cool so we launched in 2014 since
that point we have tens of thousands of customers running hundreds of thousands of workspaces it's gotten to be a pretty
common use case for our customers and so talking about that a little bit more
